content:
Isn't there a problem with the solution ?

It seems line 119 should use flyTime, not newFlight.

If I'm not mistaken, this gives an incorrect result in Validator NoClip. There, the optimal ordering is correctly found as #5, #4, zip, #2, #1, #0, #3, but computed as 38.00 total, while #0 takes more than 3" to fly, so that it's #0 fly time that should be the deciding factor (so a total of 38.63).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun puzzle!, a bit on the harder side but its fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The goal is clear from the start, and the story is quite charming. The statement provides the right amount of data to get you started, so there is no confusion about anything. Good Contribution.
Great stuff!
Wow

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A really good puzzle.

After letting this sit in the back of my mind for a few months, I came back to see what I can fix. The few edits here and there in the text don't amount to much, but this time, the test cases and validators are much tighter to conform to CodinGame conventions. I hope this version can get approved!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
That's good man

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Very nice and challenging puzzle! I tried implementing it but I can't get the test case Chug, chug, chug! to work. All other test + validators work fine. I get an output of 37.73 instead of 37.72 . I tested with JavaScript and C# to make sure it's not a language related issue. The issue is with the UFO right above you which takes a time of 3.7263... for the arrow to reach it so it rounds up to .73 in the end. I'm using the formula t = ( vy - sqrt( vy^2 - 2gy ) ) / g
I think this is a very interesting subject for a puzzle.

All of the validators are harder than the matching test case.
The last validator is significantly harder than *anything else* in the entire puzzle.

NO.
Is it allowed to drink the milkshake without going to tower 2?

Though the logic for the order of UFOs to shoot down is very easy to think of, trying to put that into the context of having multiple places to shoot from makes the puzzle much harder. It took me a lot of thinking time to come up with an O(n^2) solution, and I also had to spend a lot of time checking that it worked for the various edge cases with a brute-force O(n!) solution. Despite this, I found that this puzzle was far easier to debug and understand than my previous When Pigs Fly puzzle, so therefore I classify this puzzle as Hard.

Do you think I should provide a link to the equation for projectile motion within the statement? It's not too difficult to find it with a google search, but it's not straightforward either since it's easy to use the wrong search keywords.
Clarified the text. You can only drink a milkshake at the second watchtower.

Harder in what sense?

Edit: I see, most have more UFOs. I'd suggest increasing the tests.
I figured it out! You're using g = 9.81 m/s^2 instead of 9.8 :P. I'm not sure what (or if) I should change to make this more clear.
Great contribution, love the Oreo milkshake bit. Keep up the good work!

Dang it, thanks for the catch! My backup brute force code also confirms 38.63. I wonder if this is why the community success rate is strangely low... In any case, I updated Test NoClip to feature this edge case, as it was originally supposed to (I guess it got lost when I was redesigning the test cases).

Incidentally, this allowed me to discover an extremely obscure edge case that throws my solution's logic out the window, so... I'm not sure what to do. It's not included in the current puzzle, and I'll try to see if I can exclude it using the constraints section somehow.

Thanks for allowing my code to reach 100% validation !

My logic may be a bit simpler than yours, I don't know if it may go through your new edge case. There can be no advantage to wait before taking the buff, so only at most 3 options : stay in A, move to B, or move to B and buff. The situation with or without buff is therefore the same, just with different constants. If you move, you'll need to shoot all reachable only from A, plus whatever more you want, all at cost 3" (since max fly time is less than the zip time). Then what remains from B (including those only reachable from there), starting with the longest fly time (from B ). So I think you can be sure that it can never be good to shoot from B any ufo that can be reached from both A and B while not also shooting all the ones that have a shortest fly time (from B ). So I sort ufos that can be shot from both towers by fly time from B, and test all splits, so in the end a complexity of O(#ufos) (with an additional log because of sorting).

Oh no that was very clear, I used 9.8 multiple times, but during the bug solving process I just made a mistake which I didn't catch for hours on end because I thought it was a coding / language issue... It works now, thanks!

I should certainly match the number of UFOs for the 1st test case/validator. The rest shouldn't make a difference though... at least with my C# tests. I found that 9-10 UFOs is close to the 1 second timeout for a brute force method, so that's why I think there's no difference b/w 5 vs 6 UFOs or 18 vs 29. I'll change the test cases later when I get time.
If there's no difference, by all means please change it!
Thanks! With this rule, I can reproduce the same times and pass all tests.
